results.adx_keywords: Leicester (England);Richard III, King of England;University of Leicester;Skeletons;Archaeology
results.title: Bones Under Parking Lot Belonged to Richard III
results.abstract: In one of Britain’s most dramatic modern archaeological finds, tests identified the remains of the reviled English monarch, a discovery that could lead to a reassessment of his reign.

media.caption: The skeleton found last fall near the buried ruins of the Greyfriars Priory in Leicester was confirmed on Monday by a team of experts to be that of King Richard III.
Michael Ibsen is one of two descendants of Richard III’s sister, Anne of York, whose DNA was used to confirm the identity of the skeleton found beneath a parking lot in Leicester.
media.copyright: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

media.caption: Skeletal remains found in an English parking lot, including a tortuously curved spine, were confirmed as those of Richard III.
The skeleton found last fall near the buried ruins of the Greyfriars Priory in Leicester was confirmed on Monday by a team of experts to be that of King Richard III.

results.adx_keywords: Hostages;Alabama;Murders and Attempted Murders;Dykes, Jimmy Lee

results.title: Standoff in Alabama Ends in Boy’s Rescue and Kidnapper’s Death
results.abstract: The man who held a five-year-old boy in a bunker for days was killed during a rescue operation by federal agents.

media.caption: Law enforcement personnel stationed themselves on the property of Jimmy Lee Dykes on Monday in Midland City, Ala.
Jimmy Lee Dykes

results.title: Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home
results.abstract: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, had taken a troubled fellow veteran to a gun range for a kind of therapy session, but the police said the man turned his gun on Mr. Kyle.

results.adx_keywords: Hydraulic Fracturing;Monterey (Calif);Environment;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Reserves (Natural Resources);Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline;North Dakota;California
results.title: Vast Oil Reserve May Now Be Within Reach, and Battle Heats Up
results.abstract: Monterey Shale deposits, which could turn California into the nation’s top oil-producing state, is stirring conflict between drillers and environmental interests.

media.caption: At the Midway-Sunset oil field in California, the prize lies fairly close to the surface, so the wells do not have to be very deep. The oil in the Monterey Shale is much less accessible.
Oil dripped from a stick held by Jeff Prude, a federal Bureau of Land Management employee, near the oil fields last month.
The Midway-Sunset oil field, which keeps producing crude more than a century after the Southern California oil boom.
A marker where a 1909 gusher made the field famous.
At the Midway-Sunset oil field in California, the prize lies fairly close to the surface, so the wells do not have to be very deep. The oil in the Monterey Shale is much less accessible.

results.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
results.title: U.S. Accuses S.&P. of Fraud in Suit on Loan Bundles
results.abstract: The Justice Department has filed civil fraud charges in federal court in Los Angeles against Standard & Poor's over its ratings of mortgage-related securities.

results.title: Super Bowl Ads Speak to a Generation. But Which One?
results.abstract: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.

media.caption: Tide told a tale about a “miracle” stain on a football jersey.
Volkswagen’s commercial centered on a dialect joke.
Budweiser told a touching story about a Clydesdale foal and its trainer.
In Oreo’s ad, a debate in a library over the cookies got out of hand.
Tide told a tale about a “miracle” stain on a football jersey.

results.title: Police Call Match-Fixing Widespread in Soccer
results.abstract: A 19-month investigation by a European intelligence agency found that nearly 700 games globally may have been fixed, with profits from the wide-ranging scandal totaling about $11 million.

media.caption: Europol’s chief, Rob Wainwright, second from left, said hundreds of games might have been fixed.
media.copyright: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

media.caption: Europol’s chief, Rob Wainwright, second from left, said hundreds of games might have been fixed.
media.copyright: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Beyoncé Silences Doubters With Intensity at Halftime
results.abstract: Beyoncé answered her critics during her halftime performance by singing live with fierceness and confidence. Late in her set, she was joined by her former sidekicks of Destiny’s Child.

media.caption: Beyoncé opened her halftime performance with a serious tone, singing her hit “Love on Top.” Her voice was fierce and powerful for “Crazy in Love.”
media.copyright: Jed Jacobsohn for The New York Times

media.caption: Beyoncé opened her halftime performance with a serious tone, singing her hit “Love on Top.” Her voice was fierce and powerful for “Crazy in Love.”
media.copyright: Jed Jacobsohn for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder;Adderall (Drug);Mental Health and Disorders;Psychiatry and Psychiatrists;Fee, Kathy;Fee, Rick;Fee, Richard;Suicides and Suicide Attempts;Ellison, Waldo M;Dominion Psychiatric Associates (Virginia Beach, Va)
results.title: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
results.abstract: The suicide of Richard Fee highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.

media.caption: Before his addiction, Richard Fee was a popular college class president and aspiring medical student. "You keep giving Adderall to my son, you're going to kill him," said Rick Fee, Richard's father, to one of his son's doctors.

MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC Dominion Psychiatric Associates in Virginia Beach, where Richard Fee was treated by Dr. Waldo M. Ellison. After observing Richard and hearing his complaints about concentration, Dr. Ellison diagnosed attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and prescribed the stimulant Adderall.
media.copyright: Matt Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: COLLEGE YEARS Richard Fee was on the baseball team at Greensboro College.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: PARENTS Kathy and Rick Fee with a photograph of Richard, who committed suicide in November 2011. They say they begged his doctors not to prescribe Adderall, an amphetamine to which he had become addicted. One of Richard’s doctors later said that his was a textbook case of the ways A.D.H.D. practices can fail patients.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: QUESTIONNAIRE Richard Fee first received a diagnosis of A.D.H.D. in 2009, during a visit to a psychiatric clinic where he filled out a survey rating symptoms on a 0-to-3 scale. Having used stimulants in college to study, Richard appeared to have faked his responses in order to get a prescription.
PSYCHIATRIST Dr. Charles Parker was one of the doctors who saw Richard Fee.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: SNAPSHOT Rick and Richard Fee at Yankee Stadium in November 2009. As Richard’s addiction worsened, he became more violent and eventually was asked to leave his parents’ home.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: Before his addiction, Richard Fee was a popular college class president and aspiring medical student. "You keep giving Adderall to my son, you're going to kill him," said Rick Fee, Richard's father, to one of his son's doctors.

results.adx_keywords: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships;Supreme Court;Defense of Marriage Act (1996);Verrilli, Donald B Jr
results.title: Obama’s Shifts May Affect U.S. Legal Plan on Gay Marriage
results.abstract: After advocating a state-by-state approach to the issue, President Obama seems now be thinking nationally, complicating the strategy in a pivotal case in California.
des_facet: SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, CIVIL UNIONS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS

media.caption: Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr.  spoke outside the Supreme Court building in 2008. He will argue before the court in a pair of momentous same-sex marriage cases in March.
Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr.  spoke outside the Supreme Court building in 2008. He will argue before the court in a pair of momentous same-sex marriage cases in March.

results.adx_keywords: Mercedes Benz Superdome (New Orleans);Super Bowl;Baltimore Ravens;San Francisco 49ers;Power Outages and Blackouts;Football
results.title: Before Game Is Decided, Superdome Goes Dark
results.abstract: The lights on one half of the Superdome’s roof suddenly went out, making for one of the oddest, most embarrassing moments in Super Bowl history.

media.caption: A security guard Sunday during the power failure at the Super Dome in New Orleans, with the emergency lights on.
San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick on the field during the power failure. He later led the Niners back from a 28-6 deficit.
media.copyright: Jed Jacobsohn for The New York Times

media.caption: A security guard Sunday during the power failure at the Super Dome in New Orleans, with the emergency lights on.

results.adx_keywords: Geisel, Theodor Seuss;New York Public Library;Hats and Caps;Books and Literature
results.title: The Author Himself Was a Cat in the Hat
results.abstract: A tour featuring hats from the collection of Theodor Geisel, also known as Dr. Seuss, will begin Monday at the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue building.

media.caption: This hat from Theodor Geisel's collection resembles the one worn by the Cat in the Hat.
The Cat in the Hat.
A hat familiar to readers of the Dr. Seuss book "The 500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins."
Geisel in a San Diego State band hat, with his wife, Audrey.
This hat from Theodor Geisel's collection resembles the one worn by the Cat in the Hat.

results.adx_keywords: Koch, Edward I;Temple Emanu-el;New York City
results.title: In Words and Unmistakable Song, Koch’s Bond With City Is Celebrated
results.abstract: Politicians from across the political spectrum filled the sanctuary Monday morning at Edward I. Koch’s funeral at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.

media.caption: “Tough and loud, brash and irreverent, full of humor and chutzpah — he was our city’s quintessential mayor.”  — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, eulogizing former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
An honor guard brought the coffin of former Mayor Edward I. Koch to Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue.
Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg, Rudolph W. Giuliani and David N. Dinkins at Mayor Edward I. Koch’s funeral Monday.

results.adx_keywords: Manuscripts;Timbuktu (Mali);Libraries and Librarians;Defense and Military Forces;Tombs and Tombstones;Tuareg (Ethnic Group)
results.title: As Extremists Invaded, Timbuktu Hid Artifacts of a Golden Age
results.abstract: Residents found ways to hide delicate artifacts from the Islamists who reigned over the city until last weekend, when fighters set fire to dozens of ancient manuscripts.

media.caption: Abdoulaye Cissé of the Ahmed Baba Institute with a manuscript that was hidden from extremists, who set fire to others.
Ancient manuscripts that were saved from being burned at the Ahmed Baba Institute, the city’s biggest and most important library.
A man watched television, which was forbidden by Islamic militants while they held sway in the city until the arrival of French and Malian troops
A tomb destroyed by the extremists.
Abdoulaye Cissé of the Ahmed Baba Institute with a manuscript that was hidden from extremists, who set fire to others.

results.adx_keywords: CBS Corporation; Football; Moonves, Leslie; New Orleans (La); Nielsen Media Research; Power Outages and Blackouts; Ratings (Audience Measurement); Super Bowl; Television
results.title: Blackout Is a Boon for Super Bowl Ratings
results.abstract: The interruption was not only a diversion, but also changed the momentum in the game, helping to retain an audience that otherwise might have tuned out.

media.caption: A field judge on the Superdome playing field after the lights went out in the second half of the Super Bowl.

results.title: Bolshoi Director Accuses Rivals
results.abstract: Sergei Filin, who was severely burned by an acid attack, said he believes he may have been targeted by a group of people who hoped to replace the theater’s leadership.

media.caption: The artistic director of the Bolshoi ballet, Sergei Filin, left a hospital in Moscow on Monday.
The artistic director of the Bolshoi ballet, Sergei Filin, left a hospital in Moscow on Monday.

results.byline: By DAVID E. SANGER, ERIC SCHMITT and JODI RUDOREN
results.title: Israeli Strike Into Syria Said to Damage Research Site
results.abstract: The weapons research center has been the target of sanctions because of intelligence suggesting that it was the training site for engineers who worked on chemical and biological weaponry.
des_facet: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

media.caption: Rebel fighters received instructions during heavy fighting on Sunday in Damascus. Rebels’ cellphone videos showed damage caused by an Israeli raid Wednesday.
A Free Syrian Army fighter was wounded by a sniper in Damascus on Sunday. An Israeli airstrike last week showed cracks in Syria’s system of defense.

results.title: The Boys at the Back
results.abstract: Boys are being left behind in educational advancement. We need to address the reasons.
